School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Nanyang Technological University Singapore 639798 Singapore Ni catalysts are used widely in tar reforming for syngas purification. This study investigates the aim of the reduction stage toward Ni catalysts during tar reforming in the presence of syngas impurities. A NiAl2O4 catalyst was used for the reforming of a mixture of tar model compounds (naphthalene, toluene, and styrene) in simulated syngas containing 50 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl. The catalyst exhibited activity in tar reforming even without the pre-reduction treatment, but it was deactivated rapidly due to the favored reaction between H2S and Ni2+ species, causing increased Ni agglomeration and carbon deposition. Pre-reduction of catalysts enhanced the catalyst stability even in the presence of syngas impurities. Higher reforming activity was achieved by increasing the reduction temperature from 800 °C to 900 °C. However, transformation in the support structure at higher reducing temperature could lead to decreased exposure of Ni due to the collapse of pore structures. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic reforming Reduction Tar model compound Nickel catalyst Sintering 1 Introduction Tar generated from the thermal decomposition of organic material (e.g., waste and biomass) consists of aromatic hydrocarbons such as toluene, naphthalene, styrene, and others [1,2]. These cause challenges during downstream applications of syngas, which may require a purification step [3,4]. Catalytic tar reforming is considered a potential syngas purification process as it can be operated at temperatures close to the outlet of the gasifier. This high-temperature process eliminates the requirement for gas cooling to remove tar compounds and maintain thermal efficiency [5]. The preferred catalysts used for tar reforming are Ni-based due to their low Ni cost and wide availability [6]. Ni-based catalysts were initially developed for methane steam reforming, after which they were found suitable also for tar reforming [7,8]. Typically, Ni catalysts undergo calcination during the production process that converts Ni species into oxide and spinel compounds. These species can be reduced with H2 prior to reforming to maximize active metal content, namely Ni0 (Eq. 1). The reduction of NiO with H2 proceeds through the following steps: (1) dissociation of H2 over NiO (2) diffusion of H atoms over the Ni surface towards the reduction centers, (3) breaking of Ni-O bonds to form Ni0, (4) nucleation of Ni0 forming clusters of metallic Ni and (5) growth of metallic Ni clusters to form crystallites. These Ni0 crystallites allow the sorption of reactants on the catalyst surface and activate the steam/CO2 reforming of hydrocarbon. (1) NiO + H 2 → Ni + H 2 O It was previously reported that Ni/Al2O3 catalyst could be used for dry CH4 reforming (CH4:CO2:He = 10:10:80 on a volume basis) without pre-reduction and the conversion efficiency was comparable to the pre-reduced catalyst (84% and 87% CH4 conversion, respectively) [9]. Other studies demonstrated that without pre-reduction, Ni catalysts have high activities during steam reforming of various hydrocarbons, including acetic acid [10], ethanol [11–14], acetone [11], furfural [11], glucose [11], phenol [12,13,15], methanol and naphthalene [15]. One of the limitations of these studies is that the testing of catalysts was conducted using model gas compositions that are different from the actual syngas generated during gasification of biomass or waste. Actual syngas, consisting of H2, CO, CO2, H2O, often contain impurities such as S-based compounds, halogens, and others [16–18]. In pre-reduced catalysts, chemisorption of sulfur compounds onto the active Ni forms the inactive Ni-S complex, while halide compounds chemisorb onto the active Ni and increase the surface mobility of the Ni-halide species, which leads to an increased Ni sintering [19–24]. Many studies have focused on the steam reforming of tar model compounds [25–29], as well as removal of model tar in the presence of impurities [19,24,30]. However, tar reforming studies using conditions simulating real conditions, as well as with the use of a mixture of tar compounds and impurities, are still lacking. Such operations can be complex due to the multiple components in the gas feed. Furthermore, it is not well understood how the exposure to syngas containing multiple tar components and impurities can affect the activity of Ni catalysts in its pre-reduced and as-calcined state. Such information could shed light on the development of effective strategies for the application of tar reforming catalysts in practical conditions of municipal solid waste gasification. This study examined the influence of the pre-reduction stage on the tar reforming activity of Ni catalysts in syngas containing main gas components and impurities such as HCl and H2S. A NiAl2O4 catalyst was used due to the high stability and activity of Ni aluminate catalysts in the presence of impurities attributing to a strong Ni and Al2O3 support interaction [20,21]. Ni particles in such catalysts are highly dispersed and thermo-physically stable due to the formation of Ni-O-Al interfaces that prevent Ni agglomeration [31–33]. The as-calcined catalyst and other counterparts pre-reduced at different temperatures were used to reform naphthalene, toluene, and styrene in the gas stream. Those three components are the main stable tar compounds in syngas from biomass and waste [1,34]. The gas composition was prepared to simulate the composition of actual syngas from gasification (H2 9 vol%, CO2 9 vol%, CO 10 vol%, H2O 24 vol%, 500 ppmv HCl and 50 ppmv H2S) [35,36]. The structural changes in the as-calcined and pre-reduced catalysts upon exposure to syngas were characterized and associated with differences in catalytic activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The NiAl2O4 catalyst (14 wt% Ni) was prepared using a hydrothermal method. Urea was used as a precipitant and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as a surfactant to improve the dispersion of Ni particles. 1.7506 g nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)·6 H2O, Sigma-Aldrich), 15.08 g aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)30.9 H2O, Sigma Aldrich), 5.552 g urea (CO(NH3)2, Sigma-Aldrich) and 1.4037 g CTAB (CH3(CH2)15N(Br)(CH3)3, Sigma Aldrich) were mixed in deionized water to make up a 120 mL solution and sonicated until homogenization. The solution was poured into a 200 mL capacity autoclave reactor and heated to 180 °C for 18 h in an oven. Once the reaction was completed and the solution cooled, the precipitate produced was separated by centrifugation and washed with water for 3–4 times. The precipitate collected was dried overnight at 100 °C in an oven and further calcined for 3 h at 650 °C in air (5 °C min−1 ramping rate). The calcined catalyst was crushed and sieved to obtain 150–315 µm particle sizes for catalytic evaluation. 2.2 Tar reforming The catalyst activity was tested in a tar reforming setup, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Naphthalene, toluene, and styrene were used as model tar compounds for the reforming, as these are the most prevalent tar compounds produced from the gasification of biomass and solid waste [1,34,37,38]. Naphthalene was vaporized using an evaporator and introduced into the gas feed with an N2 gas stream. Toluene and styrene were introduced into the gas stream with a syringe pump connected to the gas line. Another syringe pump filled with an aqueous solution of HCl was used to introduce steam and HCl. Gas lines were heated to above 150 °C to prevent condensation of gas components. In each test, a quartz reactor fitted with a 50–90 µm fritted disc was packed with 0.3 mL catalyst. Two types of experiments were conducted to investigate the influence of catalyst reduction. In one group of experiments, a freshly synthesized catalyst containing Ni in the oxidized state or Ni2+, hereafter referred to as “as-calcined” catalyst, was heated to 800 °C (heating rate = 15 °C min−1) in a pure N2 with 50 mL min− 1 flow and allowed to stabilize at this temperature for 15 min prior to the reforming. No pre-reduction of the catalyst was carried out before reforming. In another group of experiments, the catalysts were reduced in 20 vol% H2/N2 from room temperature and heated with a rate of 15 °C min−1 to 800 900, or 1000 °C and maintained at those temperatures for 30 min prior to the reactions. The catalysts were denoted as “pre-reduced-T”, where T is the corresponding reduction temperature. Tar reforming was carried out at 800 °C in a gas stream mixture containing 0.13 vol% naphthalene, 0.13 vol% toluene and 0.13 vol% styrene –50 ppmv H2S – 500 ppmv HCl – 24 vol% H2O – 9 vol% H2 – 9 vol% CO2 – 10 vol% CO (wet basis) and balance N2. The total gas flow rate was 200 mL-STP min−1 (GHSV = 40 000 h−1). Samples for tar and gas were collected for 5 h at hourly intervals. For the gas sampling procedure, gas was streamed for 5 min into Tedlar bags, and the gas content was analyzed using a calibrated GC (Agilent 7890B) equipped with a flame ionization detector and two thermal conductivity detectors. Sampling for tar compounds was carried out using a pump (Gilian GilAir Plus) directing a 200 mL gas flow through solid phase adsorption (SPA) tube packed with aminopropyl-bonded silica gel (500 mg Bond Elut NH2, 3 mL, Agilent). 2 mL of dichloromethane was used to elute naphthalene, toluene, and styrene from the SPA tubes. The eluate was collected into a vial and diluted to obtain a 1:10 ratio of eluate to dichloromethane. Naphthalene, toluene, and styrene were quantified with a calibrated GC-MS (Agilent 7890B GC and 5977 A MSD). The reforming experiments were triplicated, and the results are expressed as averages of experimental runs ± standard deviations. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The fresh, pre-reduced and spent catalyst samples were characterized by several techniques. Morphology of catalyst was characterized using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM-7600 F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-1400Plus) with an accelerating voltage of 120 kV. Ni, Al, S, Cl, and C elemental mappings of the catalysts were taken with an Energy-Dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDX, Oxford Instruments) coupled to the FESEM and TEM. ImageJ software was used to calculate the diameters of 150–200 Ni particles, which were assumed to be spherical, in the pre-reduced and spent catalysts to obtain the Ni particle size distribution. BET specific surface areas and total pore volumes were quantified using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 Analyzer from the measurement of N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at − 196 °C. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were analyzed by a X-ray diffractometer with a Cu-Kα radiation source (PANalytical XPert Pro XRD). Ni reducibility of the fresh catalyst was measured with a temperature programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) carried out in a 30 mL min−1 flow rate gas mixture of 5% H2/Ar with temperatures from 50° to 900°C (5 °C min−1 ramping rate). The catalyst was pre-treated with 5% O2/Ar at 600 C for 30 min to remove any impurities and cooled to room temperature prior to the TPR test. Ni dispersion and active Ni surface area at different reduction temperatures were determined through H2-pulse chemisorption (Autochem II 2920) at 40 °C. The catalyst samples were firstly reduced in-situ with a 50 mL min−1 flow rate of 10% H2/Ar at 800 900 and 1000 °C for 30 min (10 °C min−1 ramping rate) and cooled to room temperature. H2 pulses were injected until the eluted peak areas were constant. Ni, Al, S and Cl surface contents of the spent catalysts were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a Kratos Axis Supra Spectrophotometer with dual anode monochromatic Kα excitation source. XPS analysis of the pre-reduced samples were obtained ex-situ; samples were kept in a N2 atmosphere as much as possible and the data was collected within 1–2 days after pre-reduction. CASA XPS software was used to process the XPS peaks, and analysis of the binding energies of Ni, Al, S, and Cl were corrected against an adventitious carbon C 1 s with a binding energy of 284.8 eV. Carbon and sulfur content in the spent catalysts were obtained with a CHNS elemental analyzer (Elementar Vario EL Cube). The structural form of carbon deposited was characterized by Raman spectroscopy using a laser wavelength of 532 nm (XploRA PLUS, Horiba Scientific). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst properties SEM and TEM images of the freshly synthesized catalyst are shown in Fig. 2a-b and Fig. 2c, respectively. The elemental mappings of Ni, Al and O in Fig. 2a shows that Ni is well dispersed throughout the catalyst. This as-calcined catalyst consists of compact nanoflake structures with lengths and widths of 40–150 and 10–45 nm, respectively. Besides, high resolution TEM analysis (Fig. 2d) showed a lattice spacing of 0.46 nm correlating to the γ -Al2O3 (111) plane. This result was slightly different from the reported lattice spacing of the (111) plane (0.45 nm) [39] and was attributed to the low crystallinity of γ -Al2O3 which limited the accuracy in measurement. The XRD profile ( Fig. 3a) of the as-calcined catalyst showed a mixture of broad γ -Al2O3 (PDF #00–050–0741) and NiAl2O4 (PDF #01–071–0963) peaks, indicating that the Ni was finely dispersed throughout the catalyst support through the diffusion of Ni2+ into the Al2O3 lattice leading to the formation of NiAl2O4. No NiO peaks were observed in the XRD profiles, implying that all Ni was in the NiAl2O4 form or the NiO particles were nanocrystalline and/or highly dispersed. The broad peaks observed in the XRD profile also indicated the non-crystalline structure of the amorphous and porous γ -Al2O3 support [40]. The formation of NiAl2O4 was confirmed by TPR analysis (Fig. 3b), showing a reduction peak at 770 °C, which can be assigned to the reduction of Ni2+ in NiAl2O4, while a minor peak at ~360 °C is also present indicating the presence of a small amount of NiO [41–43]. Regarding the chemical surface states from XPS profile of the catalyst (Fig. 3c), the Ni 2p3/2 binding energy (BE) was found at 856 eV with a shake-up satellite peak at 862 eV. This BE of Ni 2p3/2 is in the range of 856–857 eV, indicating Ni2+ located at the sample surface as NiAl2O4 spinel [43,44]. The catalyst had a porosity of 0.50 mL g−1 and a surface area of 176 m2 g−1. The high dispersion and high porosity of NiAl2O4 were ascribed to the porous and amorphous nature of γ -Al2O3 support [40]. 3.2 Effect of catalyst reduction on tar reforming The as-calcined and pre-reduced-800 NiAl2O4 catalysts were firstly tested for reforming. Catalyst activity during the reforming of toluene, naphthalene, and styrene with 50 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl is shown in Fig. 4. It should be noted that the catalytic reforming of those molecules only occurs over Ni0 atoms as the active sites. Interestingly, the as-calcined catalyst with mainly Ni2+ species also showed activity. This phenomenon can be explained by the formation of the Ni0 species by the reducing agents (H2 and CO) presented in the simulated syngas. The initial conversion of naphthalene over the as-calcined catalyst was only 45%, and this value rapidly dropped and fluctuated in the range of 10% − 30% over 5 h on stream. In contrast, this naphthalene conversion over the pre-reduced catalyst was significantly higher (75%), and it slightly decreased and stabilized at 61% over the same time on stream (Fig. 4a). Similarly, the styrene conversion over the pre-reduced catalyst was more stable than the as-calcined catalyst. Indeed, styrene was almost fully converted during the experiment with pre-reduced catalyst, showing conversion maintained between 98% and 96% over 5 h on stream, while this value decreased to 90% on the as-calcined catalyst (Fig. 4c). The toluene conversion efficiencies for as-calcined and pre-reduced catalysts were similar. The as-calcined catalyst had an initial conversion efficiency of 73%, decreasing to 46% after 5 h on stream. Similarly, toluene conversion decreased from an initial conversion of 67–50% over 5 h on stream on the pre-reduced catalyst (Fig. 4b). According to these results, the activity and selectivity in the reforming of those tar model compounds were detrimentally affected by the pre-reduction stage of the Ni catalyst, even though syngas contained significant quantities of reductive agents (H2 and CO). These results are different from other studies in which the comparison of pre-reduced and as-calcined catalysts was also examined [10,11]. They showed similar activities for both catalysts when CH4 and acetic acid were reformed, using simple gas composition and not accounting for the contamination of syngas by impurities. Since the molar contents of each tar compound were similar in the gas feed, the different selectivity of catalyst towards the reforming of the three tar compounds could be attributed to the differences in molecular structure [45,46] as well as in thermal stability of molecules at reforming conditions [1]. Additionally, toluene and styrene are more prone to cracking than naphthalene, which suggests the higher conversions could be due to the decomposition by both reforming and cracking reactions [47]. The similar toluene and styrene conversion rates for the as-calcined and pre-reduced catalyst was due to decomposition of the tar compounds by cracking. Overall, the high conversion rates and stability in tar reforming can be achieved on a pre-reduced catalyst to purify syngas containing typical gas components and impurities, such as HCl and H2S. The reforming activity of the NiAl2O4 catalyst in the presence of impurities was compared with other previously reported Ni catalysts ( Table 1). Taking into account the competing reactions on the active Ni sites in the presence of a mixture of tar compounds and the high GHSV value, the activity of the pre-reduced NiAl2O4 catalyst used in this study is comparable to other catalysts used for tar reforming under similar conditions with H2S and/or HCl as impurities. Furthermore, the focus in this study is on the activity of the catalyst in complex conditions, for which such studies are lacking. The comparable reforming activity for the NiAl2O4 catalyst to other catalysts used in simpler conditions suggests the potential for the catalyst to be considered for industrial purposes. Through the findings in study, long term stability studies can then be carried out for the next stage industrial use. Previous studies have shown that H2S preferentially reacts with oxidized Ni species compared to metallic Ni [20]. According to the modeling using HSC Chemistry 9 software, the probable reactions between Ni2+ compounds and H2, CO, H2S, and HCl could proceed as follows: (2) NiO + H 2 → Ni + H 2 O ∆ G= - 46.5 kJ mol - 1 (3) Ni Al 2 O 4 + H 2 → Ni + γ- Al 2 O 3 + H 2 O ∆ G= - 30.0 kJ mol - 1 (4) NiO + CO → Ni + CO 2 ∆ G= - 47.0 kJ mol - 1 (5) Ni Al 2 O 4 + CO → Ni + γ- Al 2 O 3 + CO 2 ∆ G= - 30.5 kJ mol - 1 (6) NiO + H 2 S → NiS + H 2 O ∆ G= - 76.7 kJ mol - 1 (7) Ni Al 2 O 4 + H 2 S → NiS + γ- Al 2 O 3 + H 2 O ∆ G= - 46.0 kJ mol - 1 (8) NiO + 2 HCl → Ni Cl 2 + H 2 O ∆ G= + 10.5 kJ mol - 1 (9) Ni Al 2 O 4 + 2 HCl → Ni Cl 2 + γ- Al 2 O 3 + H 2 O ∆ G= + 27.0 kJ mol - 1 (10) Ni + H 2 S → NiS + H 2 ∆ G= - 30.3 kJ mol - 1 (11) Ni + 2 HCl → Ni Cl 2 + H 2 ∆ G= + 57.0 kJ mol - 1 (12) NiS + H 2 → Ni + H 2 S ∆ G= + 30.3 kJ mol - 1 (13) NiS + CO → Ni + COS ∆ G= + 57.7 kJ mol - 1 Based on Eqs. 2–7, Gibbs energies ( ΔG ) at 800 °C were negative, indicating that reactions between Ni2+ and H2S or H2/CO can spontaneously occur at the temperature used for reforming experiments. However, regarding the lower ∆ G values, reactions in Eqs. 6–7 were more thermodynamically favored than Eqs. 2–3 or Eqs. 4–5. Those comparisons provided hints for the preferable reactions between NiO or NiAl2O4 with H2S over the reduction of those Ni2+ species with H2 or CO. These findings suggest a poisoning pathway of as-calcined catalyst by H2S, which could hinder the Ni2+ reduction by CO or H2 and subsequently lower the content of available active sites for catalytic reforming. Furthermore, the NiS species are also stable in the presence of H2 and CO reductants due to the positive ∆ G values for the reactions between NiS and H2 and CO suggesting a less thermodynamically favored reaction. Therefore, the formation of NiS prevents the ability of Ni formation during reaction by H2 and CO in the syngas. TEM images of the spent catalysts were analyzed to reveal the possible change of catalyst nanostructures during the reactions ( Fig. 5). The spherical black shapes (Fig. 5a and b), which were not observed in the fresh catalyst (Fig. 2), were formed after reforming and are attributable to the agglomerated Ni particles (Fig. 5a and b). This behavior occurs probably due to the exposure to a reducing environment in the presence of sulfur and halogens [22,23,48]. Interestingly, as suggested by the larger particle size in Fig. 5b, a more severe agglomeration effect was observed in the case of the calcined catalyst without pre-reduction. This result can be explained by the sulfidation of oxidized Ni compounds, which is more favored than metallic Ni during the reforming. Indeed, the lower ∆ G was seen in the reaction of H2S with NiO (Eq. 6) compared to that with Ni (Eq. 10). This finding indicated the critical role of the reduction stage when the pre-reduced catalyst showed higher and more stable activity in the reforming of tar model compounds (Fig. 4). EDX imaging also showed clues of possible poison effects as sulfur and Cl were seen co-located with Ni, suggesting Ni-S and Ni-Cl interactions (Fig. 5a and b). Although the reactions between Ni species and HCl are not thermodynamically favored, as seen in Eqs. 8, 9, and 11, previous studies have shown that surface Ni-Cl may still be formed during reforming [1,23]. XPS characterization was performed for the spent catalysts for analysis of surface elements. It was shown that both sulfur and chloride were present on both as-calcined and pre-reduced catalysts in the survey spectra (Fig. S2), which is consistent with EDX data. Results for the quantitative XPS are summarized in Table 2, showing atomic concentrations on the surface of the spent pre-reduced and as-calcined catalyst in which the S/Ni and Cl/Ni ratios of the spent catalysts can be indicated. The ratio of S/Ni for the as-calcined catalyst was 0.19, while it was < 0.01 in the case of the pre-reduced catalyst. Additionally, CHNS elemental analysis showed that sulfur content was 1.2 wt% in the spent as-calcined catalyst and below the detection limit in the pre-reduced catalyst (Table 2). These results suggested higher sulfur chemisorption occurred over the as-calcined catalyst than the pre-reduced catalyst. This finding reconfirmed the suggested favored sulfidation of Ni2+ species, leading to a more severe agglomeration effect in the case of the as-calcined catalyst observed in TEM images (Fig. 5). In contrast, the ratio of Cl/Ni for both pre-reduced and as-calcined catalysts was similar (~0.1), suggesting that the pre-reduction process did not prevent Cl chemisorption into the catalyst. It was previously shown for tar reforming using naphthalene that while both H2S and HCl can induce Ni agglomeration, the loss of reforming activity is associated only with H2S chemisorption [20,22,49]. In addition to severe aggregation of Ni particles, Fig. 5c shows the coke formation over the surface of the spent as-calcined catalyst, while no significant coking was observed on the spent pre-reduced catalyst (Fig. 5a). These data were confirmed by CHNS analysis, suggesting 3 wt% C on the as-calcined catalyst and undetectable C quantities on the pre-reduced catalyst (Table 2). Based on the C and Ni elemental mappings in Fig. 5c, the carbon deposition was formed over the catalyst surface, blocking the Ni particles. Ni particles also appear to be dispersed and trapped within the carbon structures, suggesting that fragmentation of larger Ni particles occurred due to the carbon growth [50]. Previously, it was shown that coke formation could lead to the loss of reforming activity [51,52]. Our data suggest that sulfur poisoning and coke deposition are more severe in the tests on the catalyst without pre-reduction. To establish and differentiate the poisoning effects of sulfur and HCl poisoning on the reforming activity of the as-calcined catalyst, two additional sets of experiments were conducted for comparison: 1) reforming without H2S and HCl, and 2) reforming with 500 ppmv HCl and without H2S ( Fig. 6). It was found in both conditions that all tar compounds were almost completely reformed over at least 5 h on stream on the catalyst even without the pre-reduction stage (Fig. 6). This remarkable finding suggested the potential of the NiAl2O4 catalyst prepared in this work for a safer and more practical tar removal process where no additional hydrogen would be needed for reduction as long as the inlet syngas is free from H2S. Regarding the poisoning effects, the obtained results in Fig. 6 are consistent with previous studies on pre-reduced catalysts [20,22,49], confirming that S poisoning of the as-calcined catalyst was the main reason for the loss of reforming activity. In those studies, the loss in reforming activity was attributed solely to H2S poisoning, whereas HCl poisoning had a minor influence. Additionally, in another study, when HCl concentration was varied from 300 to 2000 ppmv, the reforming activity was not affected [23]. As such, the reforming experiments with 50 ppmv H2S and without HCl were not carried out. It was found that carbon deposition also occurred on as-calcined catalysts during reforming in the absence of H2S (0 ppmv H2S and 0 ppmv HCl, as well as 0 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl). This behavior can be seen on the TEM images of the spent as-calcined catalysts in Fig. 7a and b. However, CHNS analysis of the as-calcined catalysts in those two cases (not shown) revealed that the carbon contents were not significant (< 1 wt% C) to affect the reforming activity (Fig. 6). This is because the rate of carbon formation is highly dependent on the catalytic activity, and lower carbon formation corresponds to higher activity [53]. In contrast, the presence of 50 ppmv H2S during reforming on the as-calcined catalyst accelerated carbon deposition (3 wt% C) (Table 2). This result suggested that H2S could also increase the coking rate on the as-calcined catalyst, which probably extended the adverse effects on the catalytic activity (Fig. 6). In short, H2S was a critical cause of the deactivation of the as-calcined catalyst. It reduced the catalyst stability and selectivity towards the reforming of three tar compounds by different extents. Among those compounds, the conversion of naphthalene was negatively affected the most, followed by toluene and styrene. The Raman spectra of the spent as-calcined catalysts are shown in Fig. 7c. Two distinctive bands at ~1340 cm−1 and ~1590 cm−1 are seen on the spectrum of the as-calcined catalyst with 50 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl. These peaks correspond to the D-band and G-band of carbon, respectively. The D-band can be ascribed to amorphous carbon or graphite with structural imperfections, while the G-band corresponds to the ordered structures of graphitic carbon [54]. The IG/ID ratio of the as-calcined catalyst with impurities (50 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl) was 0.96, suggesting that carbon deposits with high structural disorder and low graphitization degree were formed during reforming [55,56]. This can explain the relatively good activity that was maintained throughout the reforming even in the presence of H2S and HCl without pre-reduction. On the other hand, due to the low carbon content in the as-calcined catalysts without impurities (0 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl, 0 ppmv H2S and 0 ppmv HCl) as determined through CHNS analysis, the carbon bands at ~1340 cm−1 and ~1590 cm−1 could not be observed. Interestingly, tar reforming reactions on the as-calcined catalyst were also found to increase the sintering of Ni particles, even when no impurities were present in the gas feed ( Fig. 8). There was, however, no impact on the catalyst reforming activity (Fig. 6). These data are consistent with previous observations made using pre-reduced catalysts, demonstrating that agglomeration of Ni did not play an important role in the deactivation of catalyst activity compared to the formation of Ni-S [22,23]. As observed by TEM imaging of the spent catalysts (Fig. 5), Ni particles appeared to be larger for the as-calcined catalyst as compared to the pre-reduced catalyst. The distribution of sintered Ni particles (Fig. 8) also showed that Ni particles were significantly larger for the spent as-calcined catalysts compared to the pre-reduced catalyst at all conditions. One reason for the accelerated agglomeration in tests on the as-calcined catalyst is the difference in reduction conditions. For instance, Ni2+ is reduced directly in the reactions on as-calcined catalysts with 9 vol% H2 and 10 vol% CO at 800 °C. By that, Ni0 particles would have been rapidly formed at this temperature as suggested by the TPR profile (Fig. 2e), and were probably more prone to agglomeration. The rapid reduction of Ni2+ leads to lower Ni dispersion, which would be result in lower activity in the case of the as-calcined catalyst in the presence of impurities [57]. On the other hand, pre-reduction of catalyst was performed gradually by increasing temperature from room temperature to 800 °C in 20 vol% H2. This difference suggested that the gradual reduction of Ni2+ over increasing temperature ensured better distribution of as-formed Ni0. Considering that as-calcined catalysts are more susceptible to sintering, coke deposition, and poisoning of active Ni sites, pre-reduction of catalysts prior to reforming of syngas containing halide and especially sulfur impurities is essential. 3.3 Effect of pre-reduction temperature on tar reforming The effect of pre-reduction temperature on the tar reforming activity was investigated ( Fig. 9). The catalytic activity towards the reforming of naphthalene, toluene, and styrene was improved when the pre-reduction temperature increased from 800° to 900°C (73%, 69% and 98% at 900 °C against 66%, 54% and 97% at 800 °C, respectively). According to the TPR profile in Fig. 3b, although the peak maximum of Ni reduction was at 770 °C, the reduction peak continued until ~870 °C, explaining why 800 °C was not sufficient for the catalyst pre-reduction. The improved activities for the catalyst pre-reduced at 900 °C could be ascribed to the increased intensity of active Ni0 species. However, the further increase in the pre-reduction temperature to 1000 °C had a detrimental impact on the reforming activity. The conversion efficiencies of naphthalene, toluene, and styrene decreased to the levels comparable with the catalyst pre-reduced at 800 °C. According to these results, while increasing reduction temperatures allowing more Ni0 formation would enhance the reforming activity, there is a limit to the optimum temperature at which the catalyst should be pre-reduced. Table 3 shows the Ni active surface of the catalysts pre-reduced at different temperatures, as determined by H2-pulse chemisorption. According to Table 3, the active Ni surface area increased from 17.9 m2 gNi −1 to 28.2 m2 gNi −1 with an increase of pre-reduction temperature from 800 °C to 900 °C and decreased thereafter. This suggests that the highest amount of active Ni0 was available for the reforming of tar compounds when the pre-reduction temperature was 900 °C, resulting in the highest tar conversion. The deconvolution of the XPS profiles of Ni 2p3/2 ( Fig. 10a) pre-reduced at 800 900, and 1000 °C shows the distribution of Ni0 and Ni2+ with corresponding binding energies of ~853 eV and ~856 eV, respectively ( Table 4). The distribution of Ni0 determined through XPS analysis also confirms that increasing the temperature for pre-reduction above 800 °C increased the amount of reduced Ni0 (29.2% at 800 °C against 33.4% and 36.0% at 900 and 1000 °C, respectively). Additionally, the Ni particle size distribution of reduced catalysts (Fig. S3) and TEM images show that Ni particle sizes were similar for catalysts pre-reduced at 800 °C and 900 °C and were well dispersed over the catalyst surface. This further confirms the increase in Ni0 content with increasing pre-reduction temperature as observed by H2-pulse chemisorption and XPS analysis. On the other hand, the reforming activity decreased at 1000 °C despite the higher content of Ni0, suggesting that there were other factors influencing the catalytic activity at this temperature. Fig. 10b shows the XRD profiles of spent pre-reduced catalysts. All catalysts contained sharp peaks corresponding to Ni (PDF #04–003–6597). In the catalyst pre-reduced at 800 °C, broad peaks corresponding to γ -Al2O3 (PDF #00–050–0741) were identified. At higher pre-reduction temperatures, the peak shift can be seen, which is attributed to the transformation of γ -Al2O3 into δ -Al2O3 (PDF #00–056–1186) and θ -Al2O3 (PDF #00–023–1009). At the same time, larger Ni particles were formed during the pre-reduction due to the sintering of the support, as found from the calculation of the Ni0 crystallite size based on the Scherrer equation from the XRD peak of Ni(111) at 2θ = ~44° ( Table 5). This sintering was accompanied by the decrease in the catalyst surface area, as shown in Table 5. The BET surface areas of the pre-reduced catalysts before reforming also decreased at the higher temperature. Similar thermal effects were reported previously, demonstrating that during the phase transformation of alumina from γ → δ→ θ → α, the alumina particles undergo nucleation leading to decreased surface area and porosity [58,59]. According to the obtained results, the sintering of alumina support, causing the collapse of porous network and loss of access to the active Ni sites, is one of the main factors for the loss of reforming activity after pre-reduction at excessively high temperature. This observation was further confirmed through H2-pulse chemisorption experiments, which showed that both the Ni dispersion and Ni active surface area decreased as pre-reduction temperature was increased to 1000 °C (Table 3) due to the increased sintering of Ni particles and support. The losses in Ni dispersion and active surface area resulted in the decreased tar conversion for the catalyst pre-reduced at 1000 °C compared to 900 °C. Additionally, as the temperature for pre-reduction is increased from 900° to 1000°C, the increase in Ni0 content was lower than the increase of Ni0 between 800 and 900 °C pre-reduction temperature (Table 4). However, Al2O3 phase changes and decrease in BET surface area were more drastic for pre-reduction temperature between 900 and 1000 °C. Notably, the surface area of catalysts decreased further after 5 h on stream of reforming (Table 5), implying that the support transformation and sintering continued beyond the pre-reduction stage. This behavior could be a possible reason for the decreased conversion efficiencies of tar compounds after 5 h compared to the initial values. Visual observation of the support morphology shows similar nanoflake structures for all spent catalysts, suggesting that while some changes in the alumina phase are observed in XRD, these changes are not seen physically through TEM imaging (Fig. 5a, Fig. 11a and Fig. 11b). The formation of carbon on catalyst reduced at 1000 °C is evident from TEM characterization of the spent catalysts (Fig. 11a). This is different from the spent catalysts pre-reduced at 800 and 900 °C (Fig. 5a and Fig. 11b), exhibiting no visual sign of coking. EDX analysis confirms that the structures observed on the catalyst surface are indeed carbon. The carbon was filamentous in nature and was formed through a tip-growth mechanism [60], as observed in Fig. 11c, showing Ni particles found on the tip of the carbon nanofibers. The carbon deposition could be ascribed to tar cracking reactions on the Ni particles followed by the dissolution of carbon in the Ni lattice and which is then transferred to the Ni-support interface. As more carbon is deposited at the Ni-support interface, the Ni particle is lifted from the support. It is possible that due to the changes in the support structure, the formation of filamentous carbon was thus enabled under the reforming conditions [61]. However, previous studies have found that the filamentous carbon formed through the tip-growth mechanism may not detrimentally affect the reforming activity in the short term [62–64]. This is because the Ni particles at the tip of the carbon nanotubes/ nanofibers are still accessible for reforming reactions and remain active during reforming. Furthermore, CHNS analysis indicated that the carbon content was below detectable limits, suggesting that the carbon formed did not interfere with the reforming activity significantly. Additionally, the Raman spectra of the spent pre-reduced catalysts (Fig. S4) did not show the identifiable D- and G-bands for carbon, suggesting negligible carbon deposition [31]. These findings explain the relatively high tar conversion rates for the catalyst pre-reduced at 1000 °C. The Ni 2p3/2 XPS profiles of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. Similar to the XPS of the reduced catalysts, the Ni 2p3/2 profiles of the spent catalysts contained peaks at binding energies of ~852–853 eV and 856 eV, which correspond to the Ni0 and Ni2+ peak, respectively. A peak at ~861 eV corresponds to the satellite peak. The Ni0 binding energy for the spent catalyst pre-reduced at 1000 °C shifted to lower BE (Table S1), suggesting that the interaction between Ni particles and the support decreased [65,66]. The weaker interaction was due to the increased sintering of Ni (Table 4) and the decreased surface area of support allowing carbon to be formed through the tip-growth mechanism. Cl 2p profiles of the spent catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. The peak at BE between ~195–205 eV suggests Cl was chemisorbed on the Ni particles. According to Oemar et al., S 2p XPS can be studied to determine the nature of sulfur species in the spent catalyst [67]. However, due to the low content of sulfur on the spent pre-reduced catalysts (Table S2), the S 2p peaks cannot be distinguished easily. Nevertheless, these findings indicate that for the catalysts pre-reduced at different temperatures, the reforming activity in the presence of H2S and HCl could be dependent on the availability of the active Ni sites. 4 Conclusions This study has shown that the pre-reduction stage of Ni catalysts is important in maintaining stable and high activities during the reforming of tar in syngas containing impurities. Remarkably, NiAl2O4 catalyst could maintain high reforming activities of tar model compounds in H2S-free syngas over at least 5 h on stream even without prior reduction. However, the presence of H2S in the gas mixture caused a significant deactivation of this Ni catalyst. This was because H2S preferentially reacts with oxidized Ni particles, resulting in a lower amount of Ni2+ that can be reduced directly by the H2 or CO present in syngas during reforming. Additionally, this impurity also accelerated the Ni agglomeration and carbon deposition. In contrast, the pre-reduction stage of Ni catalysts can increase the stability of Ni catalysts against those deactivation pathways. The temperature used during this pre-reduction of the catalyst was also an important factor in improving catalyst activity. The catalytic activity can be improved by increasing the temperature of the pre-reduction stage, i.e., from 800 °C to 900 °C. However, further increasing the reduction temperature may lead to a negative effect in tar reforming due to undesired transformation of the support structure. These results in this study could contribute to more information on developing strategies to enhance catalytic activity and prolong the catalyst life during the upgrading of actual syngas. coredata.dc:description: Ni catalysts are used widely in tar reforming for syngas purification. This study investigates the aim of the reduction stage toward Ni catalysts during tar reforming in the presence of syngas impurities. A NiAl2O4 catalyst was used for the reforming of a mixture of tar model compounds (naphthalene, toluene, and styrene) in simulated syngas containing 50 ppmv H2S and 500 ppmv HCl. The catalyst exhibited activity in tar reforming even without the pre-reduction treatment, but it was deactivated rapidly due to the favored reaction between H2S and Ni2+ species, causing increased Ni agglomeration and carbon deposition. Pre-reduction of catalysts enhanced the catalyst stability even in the presence of syngas impurities. Higher reforming activity was achieved by increasing the reduction temperature from 800 °C to 900 °C. However, transformation in the support structure at higher reducing temperature could lead to decreased exposure of Ni due to the collapse of pore structures.
coredata.dc:title: Unravelling the significance of catalyst reduction stage for high tar reforming activity in the presence of syngas impurities
